Achieving stable heterogeneous catalysts remains a critical challenge in acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation. This study introduces a strategy to encapsulate Pd nanoparticles within TS-1 zeolite via a ligand-protection method, followed by N doping to enhance catalyst stability. It is verified that N doping onto Pd nanoparticles could modify its nanostructure and the coordination bonds, so that the thermal stability of which was significantly enhanced and the CO adsorption capability on it was improved. Moreover, the number of Lewis acid sites (LAS) or Brønsted acid sites (BAS) could be tuned by adjusting the amount of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) in the synthesis process. The increased number of acid sites enhanced the adsorption capacity of the Pd-N@TS-1(1) catalyst for acetylene, thereby mitigating the deactivation of Pd sites by C₂H₂ under CO-rich conditions. Consequently, the optimized catalyst exhibited a high dialkoxycarbonylation selectivity of 97 % with a significantly improved cycling stability over five cycles. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations revealed that the Pd-N site was the primary active center for CO activation, N doping reduced the adsorption energy of CO, promoted its enrichment, and increased the insertion frequency of CO, thereby enhanced the catalytic activity. This approach to controlling the catalytic behavior of Pd sites provides a promising strategy for designing efficient catalysts with long-term stability for acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation. Graphical abstract Description: The Pd-N nanoparticles encapsulated TS-1, designed as Pd-N@TS-1, was in situ synthesized via a ligand-protection method, which exhibited excellent performance and stability in acetylene alkoxycarbonylation due to the N doping and thus the reduction of CO adsorption energy and its enrichment. Image, graphical abstract Keywords TS-1 Pd-N nanoparticle Acid sites Acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Dimethyl maleate and dimethyl fumarate, as the products of acetylene alkoxycarbonylation, have been extensively used in various industries, including medicine, rubber, and polymers. Since the first report by Reppe in the 1930s [1,2], the design and synthesis of various kinds of catalysts for acetylene alkoxycarbonylation, has gained intensive attention. Among these, Palladium (Pd)-based catalysts have demonstrated exceptional potential owing to their high catalytic activity and selectivity [3,4]. However, the deactivation of Pd-based catalysts during the gas-liquid-solid three-phase reactions due to the metal leaching remains a great challenge [5–7]. Ding et al. synthesized a Pd/C catalyst with excellent activity by forming a single Pd site on activated carbon [8], whereas catalyst deactivation occurred due to the reduction of Pd (II) and the blockage of micropores. To address these questions, it is necessary to design or select suitable supports and active sites. TS-1 has attracted significant attention owing to its exceptional hydrothermal stability and distinctive microporous structure, and has been widely used in heterogeneous catalysts, with excellent catalytic performance [9,10]. Its special structure enhances the dispersion and utilization of noble metals and provides a suitable microenvironment for promoting reactant adsorption [11,12]. Conventional impregnation methods for zeolite-supported metal catalysts usually result in large and inhomogeneous metal particles with sintering-induced aggregation and leaching mechanisms under catalytic conditions. That is due to the fact that metal species tend to gather on the outermost part of the zeolite crystals during synthesis. The limited diffusion of dissolved metallic precursors in the small and medium pores leads to the aggregation of noble metal nanoparticles on zeolite surface, resulting in the formation of large, non-uniform particles [13–15]. Therefore, encapsulating metal nanoparticles into zeolites presents a promising strategy to enhance metal dispersion and decreased NPs size [16–18]. The inherent microporous architecture of TS-1 establishes spatial constraints that substantially suppress the agglomeration tendency and leaching propensity of metallic species [19,20]. For example, Iglesia et al. developed a ligand-stabilized approach to encapsulate a series of small metal nanoparticles into various aluminosilicate zeolites [21,22]. Yu et al. reported a ligand-protected method to encapsulate metal clusters within pure silica zeolites under direct hydrothermal conditions [23]. The size of the resulting metal nanoparticles was restricted by the channels of the zeolite, provided that the zeolite structure was well-preserved throughout the process. During these processes, ligands played a crucial role in stabilizing metal nanoparticles within the zeolite matrix. On the other hand, experimental evidence indicates that strategic modification of the localized chemical environment surrounding metal nanoparticles confined can significantly improve selectivity in catalytic processes, such as through the coordination interactions between specific nitrogen or carbon configurations and metal sites. Bai et al. reported a carbonization-reduction approach that forms Pd-C bonds within pure silicate MFI zeolite, significantly improving the selectivity in the semihydrogenation of alkynes [24]. Wang et al. reported hydrochlorination of acetylene on single-atom Pd/N-doped carbon catalysts and investigated the Pd-based catalysts with Pd-N coordination bonds [25]. It is reported that the organic ligands regulate the spatial and electronic properties of the supported metal nanoparticles, thereby adjusting their atalytic properties. J. Will Medlin et al. reported glutaraldehyde oxidation on Pd/Al2O3 coated with several thiols and DFT calculations implicate hydrogen bonding stabilizes adsorbed intermediates, improving selectivity [26]. Hu et al. prepared Pd-based catalysts with tailored physicochemical properties for formic acid electrooxidation, the introduction of propanethiol generates additional active sites and strengthens the interaction between the metal and the carbon support [27]. These findings suggest that ligand engineering can be employed to tailor the coordination environment and specific configurations of Pd active sites, thereby further enhancing the performance of acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation. Therefore, it is essential to identify the nitrogen configurations within N-doped zeolite-encapsulated metal nanoparticles that play a crucial role in acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation, as well as to understand how these nitrogen atoms interact with the Pd species. Herein, Pd nanoparticles encapsulated TS-1 zeolite were facilely synthesized by using an in situ hydrothermal method with 1,10-phenanthroline as the Pd stabilizing agent. Due to the formation of nitrogen species from the pyrolysis of 1,10-phenanthroline at high temperatures and the construction of suitable anchoring sites for Pd coordination, Pd nanoparticles were effectively confined, and the catalytic stability was thus enhanced. The formation of Pd-N bonds played a pivotal role in promoting CO enrichment, which subsequently increased the frequency of CO insertion. Additionally, by optimizing the TPAOH concentration, we were able to enhance the number of acidic centers in the catalyst, which can enhance the activation of C₂H₂ and mitigate its inhibitory effect on the activation of C₂H₂ on the Pd surface in a CO environment. Consequently, the synergistic effect of the Pd-N bonds and the abundant acidic sites significantly improved the catalytic activity of Pd-N@TS-1. 2 Computational and experimental 2.1 Materials Palladium Chloride (99 %, RG), Methyl alcohol (≥99.9 %,HPLC), Ethanol, HCl (35wt %), 1,10-Phenanthroline, tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, 98 %), Tetrabutyl Orthotitanate (TPAOH, 45wt %), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 99 %), Lsopropyl Alcohol (IPA, ≥99.7 %,GCS). all of them were purchased from Shanghai Titan Scientific Co. Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of PD-N@TS-1(x), X = 1, 2, 3 The TS-1 samples were synthesized by the hydrothermal method with TPAOH using tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (45wt %-TPAOH in aqueous solution) as organic structure-directing agent, the following composition ratio: 1SiO2/ 0.016TiO2/ 0.225TPAOH/ 0.030Pd/ 143H2O. Typically, 7.82 g TEOS was dispersed in 17.5 g deionized under stirring for 30 min. 3.9 g TPAOH solution was then added into the above mixture. After stirring at 40 °C for 2 h, followed by the addition of 0.2 g TBOT dissolved in 2 g IPA at 5 °C under vigorous stirring for 12 h. Meanwhile, A solution of 0.20 g of PdCl2 was prepared by dissolving it in 2 ml of H2O, which was then mixed with 0.24 g of 1,10-Phenanthroline, the solution obtained was subsequently introduced in a dropwise manner into the aforementioned mixture while being stirred for a duration of 10 h. The mixture was mixed with a CTAB solution (0.9 g CTAB dissolved in 75 g deionized) at 80 °C for 22 h. After stirring for 6 h, the Teflon vessels were used to transfer the white mixture, followed by the addition of 15 g ethanol. The hydrothermal treatment was then conducted under autogenous pressure at 170 °C for a duration of 72 h. The solid product was collected by filtrating, washed by water, dried at 373 K overnight called before Pd-N@TS-1(1) and calcined at 823 K for 8 h to derive the final product Pd-N@TS-1(1). Pd-N@TS-1(X), X = 1,2,3. Catalysts were synthesized in the same way, except the amount of TPAOH added were 3.9 g,5.4 g, 6.8 g. 2.3 Preparation synthesis of Pd/TS-1 The as-prepared TS-1was mixed with a certain amount of H2PdCl4 (0.20 g PdCl2 and 300 μL HCl was dissolving it in 2 ml H2O) solution in a flask in 25 °C. After sitting overnight, the obtained Pd/TS-1 was dried in the oven and calcined in air environment at 823 K for 8 h. 2.4 Preparation synthesis of Pd-N0.5@TS-1(1) It was synthesized in the same way with Pd-N@TS-1(1), except the amount of 1,10-Phenanthroline added was 0.24 g. 2.5 Catalytic activity test The acetylene carbonylation reaction was carried out in a high-pressure reaction. The high-pressure reactor contained a rupture disk, a pressure gauge, heating and stirring speed controllers. 300 mg of catalyst, 100 mg of KI and 30 mL CH3OH were sequentially added to the reaction device. After cleaning the autoclave with N2, C2H2 was injected into the reactor with a volume of 0.25 L. Then, air at a pressure of 1.6 MPa and CO at a pressure of 4.6 MPa were introduced into the system. When the temperature reached 70 °C, the reaction time is 5 h. The autoclave was then cooled to 25 °C and the exhaust gas was collected using a wet gas flow meter. The remaining gases were analyzed by Gas chromatography (GC2014), the liquids were analyzed by Agilent HP1100. The conversion of acetylene (X), selectivity (S), and yield (Y) (Dimethyl maleate, Dimethyl fumarate) were determined according to the following equations: X = ( n − n 1 ) / n × 100 % S = n ( D M M + D M F ) / ( n − n 1 ) × 100 % Y = n ( D M M + D M F ) / n × 100 % Where, n: the molar content of acetylene passed through high-pressure reaction; n1: the residual molar content of acetylene after the acetylene carbonylation reaction; n(DMM+DMF): molar content of DMM and DMF in the system after the acetylene carbonylation reaction. (DMM: Dimethyl maleate, DMF: Dimethyl fumarate) 2.6 Material characterizations X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) were obtained by Bruker XRD diffractometer using CuKα373 rays (λ = 1.54056 A) in the scanning range of 40 kV, 40 mA, 5 ∼ 90° After vacuum degassing at 376–100 °C for 4 h, N2 adsorption-desorption measurements were performed at liquid nitrogen temperature on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 PLUS physical adsorption analyzer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using the Versaprobe III. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) is performed on the tainstrument STA449F3 Analyzer. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and elemental maps were obtained by using JEOL jem-f200 microscope at 200 kV. In situ diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (In-situ DRIFTS) of the reaction process was conducted on a Bruker INVENIO S. The catalyst was loaded into an in-situ cell. A mass flow controller was used to control the gas flow rate in the autoclave. The temperature of the catalyst was raised to 373 K in an Ar atmosphere and kept for 30 min. C2H2, CO or Ar foamed C2H5OH were used as probe molecules, respectively. C2H2/CO and air were then passed through the C2H5OH at 298 K at a flow rate of 50 mL/min, respectively. After an argon purge at 393 K, the DRIFT spectra were recorded in the 800–4000 cm-1 wavelength range. The XAFS data were processed using conventional techniques, using the Athena module implemented in the IFEFFIT software packages. The EXAFS spectra were generated by removing the post-edge background from the total absorption and then normalizing with respect to the edge-jump step. The χ(k) data were Fourier converted into real (R) space using a Hanning window (dk = 1.0 Å −1) to distinguish the EXAFS contributions of distinct coordinating shells. To determine the quantitative structural parameters surrounding core atoms, least squares curve parameter fitting was done using the ARTEMIS module of the IFEFFIT software program. Temperature programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was conducted on Chembet Pulsar TPD. The acidity of the synthesized catalysts was evaluated using pyridine-adsorbed Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy. FT-IR measurements were initially performed at room temperature (25 °C). The temperature was subsequently raised to 350 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Prior to analysis, the sample was activated under vacuum conditions for 1 hour. Following background subtraction, the sample was cooled to room temperature. The sample was then exposed to pyridine vapor for 30 min until saturation. After adsorption ceased, the system was evacuated to remove unbound pyridine. Thermal desorption was conducted by heating the sample to 50 °C, 200 °C, and 350 °C under vacuum. The concentrations of Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites in the catalysts were calculated using empirical formulas derived from the experimental data. 3 Results and discussion The crystalline topologies of the Pd-N@TS-1 samples were confirmed by X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) analysis, as shown in Fig. 1 (a). Diffraction peaks at 2θ=7.8°, 8.8°, 23.2°, 23.8°and 24.5°, which correspond to the lattice plane indices of (101), (200), (501), (303), and (133), indicate the successful synthesis of TS-1 composites with a standard MFI topological structure [28]. Diffraction angles of 2θ = 33.7, 41.9 and 54.7°were attributed to the basal planes (101), (110) and (112), respectively. However, a shift of the diffraction peak to lower angles, indicating lattice expansion may be attributed to the adsorption of ions on the surface of PdO [26]. In the Fourier Transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra presented in Fig. 1(b), the characteristic peaks at 550 cm-1, 800 cm-1, and 1230 cm-1, further verify the MFI zeolite structure in Pd-N@TS-1 [29]. The absorption peak at 550 cm-1 corresponds to the characteristic absorption of the double five-membered rings in the zeolite framework, while the absorption peak at 1097 cm-1 is related to the stretching vibration of Pd-N, which preliminarily prove the successful N doping in the sample. The absorption peak at 800 cm-1 corresponds to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of the internal Si-O(SiO4) tetrahedral units, and the absorption peak at 1230 cm-1 corresponds to the asymmetric stretching vibrations of the zeolite framework [30,31]. The peak at 960 cm-1 corresponds to the Ti framework [32], the characteristic spectral feature primarily correlates with the vibrational stretching modes of Si-O-Ti chemical linkages, while the peak magnitude demonstrates a linear dependence on the framework-incorporated titanium concentration [33–35]. In addition, it is usually to use the absorption band intensity ratios of 960 cm-1 to 800 cm-1 to evaluate the relative amount of Ti species in the framework [36]. It is found that the I960/I800 value of Pd-N@TS-1(2) decreased to 1.483, compared to 1.632 of Pd-N@TS-1(1), showing that Pd-N@TS-1(2) has a reduced framework titanium content owing to the increased amount of TPAOH. The isotherms of the samples, shown in Fig. 1(c), exhibit a Type IV isotherm with hysteresis loops in the high relative pressure range (0.8 < P/P0 < 0.99), indicating the presence of mesopores and macropores formed by the packing of nanosized particles. Fig. 1(d) presents the type and coordination state of the Ti species in Pd-N@TS-1 as determined by ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance (UV–Vis) spectroscopy. As shown, the samples exhibit two distinct sets of absorption bands, in the range of λ = 210–220 nm or λ = 310–330 nm, respectively. These bands are commonly attributed to two different forms of titanium species: the band in the range of 210–220 nm corresponds to the tetrahedrally coordinated Ti, which is integrated into the framework of the TS-1 zeolite (referred to as framework Ti), while the band in the range of 310–330 nm is associated with the presence of anatase TiO2, which may form as a separate TiO2 phase [37]. Therefore, these results suggest that the treatment with TPAOH was highly effective in promoting the formation of framework Ti species, thereby enhancing the incorporation of titanium into the TS-1 framework. As typically observed for isolated tetrahedral coordination of Ti atoms, all samples show a prominent absorption peak at approximately 210 nm, indicative of a charge transfer transition from the O 2p orbitals of the oxygen atoms, coordinated to the Ti atoms, and the empty 3d orbitals of the framework Ti atoms. This charge transfer process is a key feature of tetrahedrally coordinated Ti and serves as a hallmark of the framework Ti species within the TS-1 zeolite. Notably, in addition to the absorption feature at 210 nm, the absence of the distinctive absorption peak around 330 nm, typically associated with anatase TiO2 species suggests that the TPAOH treatment successfully inhibited the formation of anatase TiO2 clusters or aggregates within the zeolite matrix. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images shown in Fig. 2 (d-f), elucidate the distributions of Pd nanoparticles into the zeolite crystals. In Pd-N@TS-1(3), some Pd nanoparticles were not fully encapsulated within the zeolite. However, with the optimization of TPAOH amount, only a few Pd particles in Pd-N@TS-1(1) failed to achieve complete encapsulation. Notably, Pd-N@TS-1(2) and Pd-N@TS-1(3) samples exhibited larger Pd clusters, suggesting that variations in the synthesis conditions influenced the size and distribution of Pd nanoparticles. It is revealed that when the TPAOH/Si ratio was set at 0.44, the average Pd nanoparticle size was approximately 12–14 nm. However, when the TPAOH/Si ratio was reduced to 0.31, the size of the Pd nanoparticles decreased to about 10–12 nm. Interestingly, when the TPAOH/Si ratio was further lowered to 0.22, the average size of the Pd nanoparticles decreased to 3–5 nm. These suggest TPAOH played a significant role in controlling the size and dispersion of Pd nanoparticles. For the Pd-N@TS-1(1) sample, the optimized concentration of TPAOH was particularly effective in enhancing the dispersion of Pd nanoparticles, resulting in a more uniform distribution and smaller nanoparticle size within the zeolite structure. This is further supported by the TEM mapping shown in Fig. 2(c), (g) and (k), where aggregation is observed in Pd-N@TS-1(2) and Pd-N@TS-1(3) samples, in contrast to the better dispersion seen in Pd-N@TS-1(1). The distribution of N within the samples, as shown in Fig. 2(d), (h), and (l), reveals nitrogen incorporation throughout all the samples. This kind of N doping is crucial for achieving the desired catalytic properties. Based on the above characterization results, a possible formation mechanism of the titanium–silicon zeolite is proposed. To suppress the formation of TiO₂, the zeolite precursor was first synthesized under low-temperature conditions. A palladium complex stabilized by 1,10-phenanthroline was then introduced, followed by an aging process at 90 °C for 24 hours [38,39]. This step promoted the formation of abundant sub-nanometer zeolite nuclei, with the Pd complex embedded in the intersecting voids of the developing framework. Subsequent hydrothermal treatment led to the formation of composite zeolite particles containing the Pd complex, the microporous structure-directing agent (TPAOH), and the mesoporous template (CTAB). Finally, calcination in air removed the organic components, resulting in titanium–silicon zeolites with embedded Pd nanoparticles stabilized by nitrogen ligands. To future investigate the N doping process, we conducted X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) analysis for Pd and N elements. As shown in Fig. 3 , Fig. S4 and S5. Binding energies at 336.6 ± 0.3 eV and 341.8 ± 0.3 eV correspond to Pd²⁺ 3d₅/₂ and Pd²⁺ 3d₃/₂, respectively, while peaks at 337.6 ± 0.3 eV and 343.2 ± 0.3 eV are attributed to Pd⁴⁺ 3d₅/₂ and Pd⁴⁺ 3d₃/₂. The coexistence of Pd²⁺ and Pd⁴⁺ species is attributed to the absence of a reducing agent during synthesis, resulting in predominantly oxidized palladium nanoparticles serve as the active centers of the catalysts from a metal valence perspective. For both Pd/TS-1 and Pd-N@TS-1(1), the slightly lower Pd 3d binding energy observed in Pd-N@TS-1(1) suggests a higher electron density. This shift means that Pd-N@TS-1(1) has a lower d-band center in Pd nanoparticles, indicating a relatively high electron density around the Pd atoms. Before N doping, Pd was exclusively coordinated with O. However, nitrogen (N) doping may result in the substitution of certain oxygen (O) atoms. Moreover, nitrogen exhibited slightly lower electronegativity than oxygen, the electron density around Pd decreased, leading to a reduction in its oxidation state. This indicates N doping enhances the oxidation of metal atoms bonded with supports, while protecting the Pd (II) from being deeply oxidized. This difference in performance between Pd/TS-1 and Pd-N@TS-1 can be attributed to the distinct electronic and structural modifications introduced by nitrogen doping. The N 1 s XPS spectra show three types of N functionalities: pyridinic-N (∼398.2 ± 0.2 eV), graphitic-N (∼401.1 ± 0.2 eV), and oxidized pyridinic-N (∼403 ± 0.2 eV). As a reference sample Pd/TS-1, no nitrogen (N) peaks were detected due to the absence of ligands. For Pd-N@TS-1(1), Pd-N@TS-1(2) and Pd-N@TS-1(3), pyridinic-N, graphitic-N and oxidized pyridinic-N were observed. However, as shown in Table S2, the Pd-N@TS-1 sample contains a higher amount of graphite-N, combining with the size distribution of Pd nanoparticle in TEM, these results demonstrate that the graphitic-N content facilitates palladium (Pd) nucleation and dispersion [40]. Hence, Pd-N@TS-1 exhibits the best metal particle dispersion. As shown in Fig. S4, a slightly lower Pd 3d binding energy for Pd-N@TS-1(1) suggests an increase in electron density, while a slightly higher N binding energy indicates a decrease in electron density. These show that nitrogen doping through ligands can alter the electronic properties of Pd. To elucidate the electronic configurations and atomic arrangements of metal species embedded within the TS-1 zeolite framework, X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) analyses were employed to examine their electronic states and coordination environments. As shown in Fig. 3(c), Pd foil with Pd-Pd peak around 2.739 Å was corresponded to Pd-Pd bonds in a metallic lattice. PdO foil exhibits both Pd-O and Pd-Pd coordination, with the Pd-O peak appearing at shorter distances (∼2.201 Å) and the Pd-Pd at larger distances (∼3.030 Å). For Pd-N@TS-1(1), the first peak (∼2.025 Å) shifts leftward compared to the Pd-O signal, indicating that Pd-N coordination replaces Pd-O coordination in the Pd-N@TS-1(1) sample, which accounts for the peak position shift. The wavelet data, marked by the dotted line, along with the position of the first wavelet peak of the sample and Pd-O, reveals a slight leftward shift in the wavelet center of the sample. This observation suggests that the atomic number of Pd in the sample is lower than that in nitrogen-coordinated oxygen. The X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra show that the white line (WL) intensity of Pd-N@TS-1(1) is close to PdO foil, indicating an oxidation state of the Pd species. The substitution of Pd-N coordination for Pd-O coordination occurs during the thermal treatment of Pd-N@TS-1(1). This Pd-N interaction modifies the electronic properties of Pd, as shown by the XPS analysis in Fig. 3(a). Compared to O, N exhibits lower electronegativity, which reduces electron withdrawal from Pd. The Pd-N and Pd-Pd signals were detected within the sample. Further simulation analysis revealed the presence of Pd-N and Pd-Pd signals in the sample, suggesting that the structure of Pd within the sample resembles Pd-N. Given that the fitting result represents the average coordination number, it is speculated that the coordination number for Pd and nitrogen atoms may be 4 or 6. The combined EXAFS and XANES analyses indicate significant structural and electronic differences among the Pd foil, PdO, and nitrogen-modified Pd sample. The nitrogen coordination in Pd-N@TS-1(1) is evident in both the radial distribution and k-R mapping, confirming a Pd-N environment that could enhance the catalytic activity by altering electronic properties. These structural distinctions suggest that the Pd-N modified sample have unique properties valuable for catalytic applications. As shown in Fig. S6, C2H2-TPD were performed to study the effect of acid sites on the adsorption property of Pd-N@TS-1(1) and Pd-N@TS-1(3) catalysts. Distinctive peaks were observed with two desorption temperature ranges (weak C2H2 desorption area:100–200 °C; strong C2H2 desorption area: 200–400 °C), the desorption area of acetylene in the order of: Pd-N@TS-1(1)> Pd-N@TS-1(3). Since the peak area reflects the adsorption capacity, it can be reasonably concluded that an increased number of acid sites enhances the acetylene adsorption capacity in Pd-N@TS-1(1) catalysts, and reduces the passivation effect of C2H2 on the Pd surface in a CO environment, thereby further improving the catalytic performance. Pyridine Infrared Spectroscopy (Py-IR) tests, which illustrate the IR spectra of the three samples following pyridine adsorption/desorption at 50, 200, and 350 °C, were further conducted to characterize the acid sites in greater detail, as shown in Fig. S7 (a), (b), and (c). Absorption bands at approximately 1446 cm-1 and 1608 cm-1 indicate the presence of Lewis acid sites (LAS) from framework Ti⁴⁺ and Brønsted acid sites (BAS) arising from hydroxyl‑containing defects in the TS-1 zeolite. At 350 °C, none of the samples displayed significant absorption peaks, confirming the absence of stable strong acid sites in the zeolite structure. Following pyridine desorption at 200 °C, minor BAS-related peaks were observed, providing further evidence of the limited BAS content in the produced zeolites. The two absorption peaks corresponding to LAS increase in intensity as catalytic performance decreases. An excess of acid sites could potentially inhibit the desired reaction. Using the integrated area of the absorption bands in the Py-IR spectra, the concentrations of acid sites (categorized by strength) and Lewis acid site (LAS) content in the three synthesized catalysts were systematically analyzed, with comprehensive data tabulated in Table S3. Among the samples, Pd-N@TS-1(1) demonstrated a significantly higher density of both strong and weak acid sites relative to Pd-N@TS-1(2) and Pd-N@TS-1(3). This observation suggests a potential correlation between elevated acid site availability and enhanced selectivity toward the desired product. The dialkoxycarbonylation reaction, as depicted in Fig. 4 (a), was performed to synthesize dimethyl maleate (DMM) and dimethyl fumarate (DMM) by utilizing acetylene, carbon monoxide, methyl alcohol, and air as the reactants. The catalytic performance of Pd/TS-1 catalyst and Pd-N@TS-1(X) catalysts (where X = 1, 2, 3) was thoroughly evaluated in a high-pressure reactor under controlled conditions to investigate their efficiency in acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the Pd/TS-1 catalyst displayed an initial acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation selectivity of 66 %. In contrast, the Pd-N@TS-1(1) catalyst demonstrated significantly improved catalytic performance, achieving an impressive 90 % acetylene conversion and 97 % selectivity for the desired dialkoxycarbonylation products. These results highlight the remarkable impact of nitrogen doping on the Pd nanoparticles, which evidently enhanced the catalytic activity, compared to the non-doped Pd nanoparticles. Given these results, the Pd-N@TS-1(1) catalyst was selected for further investigation. A critical aspect of the catalyst performance in heterogeneous catalysis is its recyclability, as it is essential for the practical application. As shown in Fig. 4(c), the Pd-N@TS-1(1) catalyst exhibited moderate stability over five reaction cycles, with very less deactivation. Meanwhile, Fig. S1 shows that the catalyst maintained a good MFI structure after 5 cycles. This demonstrates the catalyst’s ability to withstand repeated use without significant loss of activity, a desirable trait for large-scale processes. In addition, the TG behavior of the Pd-N@TS-1(1) catalyst was evaluated in air. As illustrated in Fig. S2, Pd-N@TS-1(1) exhibits negligible weight loss in air from 50 °C to 800 °C. Pd has been considered the active site for the dialkoxycarbonylation and inhibiting the loss of Pd is of great significance, as shown in Fig. S3, Pd(II) species were still present in the catalyst after five reaction cycles, and less metal leaching of the Pd-N@TS-1(1) catalyst was observed by ICP-OES after the 5th cycle compared to the fresh catalyst (Table S1), indicating that the TS-1 structure effectively inhibited metal leaching. This stability suggests that the Pd-N@TS-1(1) catalyst is highly resistant to oxidation or leaching, further confirming its robustness for extended catalytic cycles. Therefore, the successful encapsulation of N-doped Pd nanoparticles within the TS-1 matrix boosts the catalytic activity, as well as the recyclability of the catalyst. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (In-situ DRIFTS) using reaction atmosphere (C2H2, CO) was performed on the Pd/TS-1 and Pd-N@TS-1(1) catalysts at 120 °C, as shown in Fig. 5 (a) (b), S8 and S9. CO, as a probe molecule was investigated on the pure Pd/TS-1 and Pd-N@TS-1(1), respectively. The in-situ CO-DRIFTS spectrum of TS-1 is shown in Fig S8(a). Two peaks at 2168 and 2119 cm-1 were recorded, attributed to the gas-phase CO stretching vibration. There were no peaks associated with CO stretching vibration before the introduction of CO. After Ar purging, no peak appeared. Therefore, it is proposed that chemically absorbed CO did not exist in TS-1. As shown in Fig. S8(b), the weak absorption peaks at 2176 and 2116 cm-1 on Pd-N@TS-1(1) were attributed to linear CO adsorption on Pd2+ and Pd0, in which Pd0 was generated by CO reduction [41]. The in-situ C2H2-DRIFTS spectrum (C2H2 as a probe molecule) of Pd/TS-1and Pd-N@TS-1(1) are shown in Fig. S9. In Pd/TS-1, the peaks at 3310 and 3260 cm-1 were assigned to the gas-phase C2H2. After Ar purging, strong C2H2 adsorption peaks at 1361, 1719, and 3260 cm-1 persisted on Pd-N@TS-1(1), which were attributed to the PdHCCH species [42]. To simulate the true state of the catalyst during the reaction, CO, C2H2, air, and C2H5OH were introduced to the Pd-N@TS-1(1) as shown in Fig. 5(b). This led to the generation of vibrational absorption peaks corresponding to the ester group of the acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation products. Specifically, the peaks at 2998 and 2969 cm-1 on Pd-N@TS-1(1) were identified as stretching vibration peaks of the methyl and methylene groups. Specifically, the peaks at 2998 and 2969 cm-1 on Pd-N@TS-1(1) were identified as stretching vibration peaks of the methyl and methylene groups, whereas the peaks at 1739 and 1720 cm-1 were attributed to C = O bonds in the cis and trans products. CO adsorption on Pd-N sites was confirmed by peaks at 2700 and 2668 cm-1 on Pd-N@TS-1(1), indicating stronger CO adsorption. The N species (pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N), formed by high temperature roasting, increased the insertion frequency of CO and facilitated the transformation of the target products. Similarly, the CO-TPD profile quantifies the desorption of CO from the catalyst surface upon heating. As shown in Fig. S10, the desorption peak in the temperature range of 50–200 °C corresponds to molecular CO adsorption, indicating weak interaction between CO and the catalyst surface. In contrast, the desorption peak observed between 600–800 °C can be attributed to the dissociative adsorption of CO, indicating stronger interactions and higher binding energy of CO on the surface. Notably, Pd-N@TS-1(1) exhibits the largest desorption peak around 640 °C, which implies that this catalyst, containing N-doped Pd nanoparticles, has a significantly stronger capacity for CO dissociation and adsorption compared to Pd/TS-1. To gain a deeper elucidate into the unique structure of the Pd-N sites and the dialkoxycarbonylation process, DFT calculations were carried out using the CP2K code to investigate the change of reaction energy on Pd-O clusters and P-N clusters [43–45]. Compared to Pd-O nanoparticles, Pd-N nanoparticles doped with nitrogen have lower adsorption energies for CO, which is beneficial for the adsorption of CO. Based on the above results, a proposed mechanism for acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation at the Pd-N sites is illustrated in Fig. 6 . Initially, C2H2 adsorbs onto the Pd-N site, forming species (B1), which features a triple bond coordination. Subsequently, CO adsorbs onto the Pd-N site, generating species (C1). The insertion of CO into species C1 results in the formation of an acyl-palladium species (D1). Further CO insertion into species D1 leads to the formation of the diacyl-palladium species (E1). Finally, methanol attacks, yielding the 1,4-dicarboxylic acid ester products. The specific reaction can be expressed as follows: (1) C 2 H 2 → C 2 H 2 * (2) C 2 H 2 * + CO → HCCHC O * (3) HCCHC O * + CO → HCCHCO + C O * (4) HCCHCO + C O * → OCHCCHC O * (5) OCHCCHC O * + 1 / 2 C H 3 OH → H 3 COOCHCCHCOOC H 3 + 1 / 2 H * 4 Conclusion In conclusion, a novel catalyst, Pd-N@TS-1(1), consisting of N-doped Pd nanoparticles encapsulated in TS-1 zeolite has been fabricated, which was demonstrated to be efficient in acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation with a high selectivity of 97 % and cycling stability over five cycles. It was revealed that the active sites for acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation were served by the N-doped Pd nanoparticles. Notably, the catalyst performance was enhanced by the formation of Pd-N bonds, which was demonstrated effectively enhanced the adsorption of CO. Besides, it was verified that the formation of the anatase phase could be significantly decreased, and the Ti content in the framework was simultaneously increased by reducing the amount of TPAOH in the synthesis process. This modification led to a substantial improvement in the quantification of the acid sites, further improving the efficacy of the catalyst. This work offers a pathway for creating more durable and industrially applicable catalysts for acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation reactions. coredata.dc:description: Achieving stable heterogeneous catalysts remains a critical challenge in acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation. This study introduces a strategy to encapsulate Pd nanoparticles within TS-1 zeolite via a ligand-protection method, followed by N doping to enhance catalyst stability. It is verified that N doping onto Pd nanoparticles could modify its nanostructure and the coordination bonds, so that the thermal stability of which was significantly enhanced and the CO adsorption capability on it was improved. Moreover, the number of Lewis acid sites (LAS) or Brønsted acid sites (BAS) could be tuned by adjusting the amount of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) in the synthesis process. The increased number of acid sites enhanced the adsorption capacity of the Pd-N@TS-1(1) catalyst for acetylene, thereby mitigating the deactivation of Pd sites by C₂H₂ under CO-rich conditions. Consequently, the optimized catalyst exhibited a high dialkoxycarbonylation selectivity of 97 % with a significantly improved cycling stability over five cycles. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations revealed that the Pd-N site was the primary active center for CO activation, N doping reduced the adsorption energy of CO, promoted its enrichment, and increased the insertion frequency of CO, thereby enhanced the catalytic activity. This approach to controlling the catalytic behavior of Pd sites provides a promising strategy for designing efficient catalysts with long-term stability for acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation.
coredata.dc:title: 1,10-phenanthroline complexes derived N-doped Pd nanoparticle encapsulated in TS-1 zeolite for acetylene dialkoxycarbonylation
